These financial and operational requirements must be met to comply with the regulatory framework for operating a Cell Company and obtaining permission as a Captive Insurer.

question: What are the financial obligations of an Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company with a Financial Services Permission to carry on Regulated Activities as a Captive Insurer or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company must pay an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell it wishes to add after receiving its Financial Services Permission [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8]. Additionally, if this Authorised Person has permission to carry on the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must also pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company with a Financial Services Permission to carry on Regulated Activities as a Captive Insurer or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle has specific financial obligations. Firstly, such an entity must pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 to the Regulator for either or both Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle [#P:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579]. Additionally, if the Cell Company is carrying on Captive Insurance Business through its Cells, it is considered a Captive Insurer, and the relevant rules for Captive Insurers apply [#P:3e86e67a-6d1b-4071-8a8e-57ecf5aee94e]. Furthermore, if the Cell Company is involved in these activities, it may incur additional fees as specified in Rules 3.11.5 to 3.11.7, which are supplementary to those outlined in Rules 3.11.1 to 3.11.4 [#P:dec31cbb-1377-4ccf-9b40-b8810ee6a2af]. These obligations ensure that the Cell Company complies with the financial regulatory requirements set by the Regulator for operating within the ADGM framework.

question: If a company is a Cell Company and also does insurance activities, what fees does it have to pay?
gold_answer: A company that is a Cell Company must pay $1,000 for each new Cell it adds after getting its Financial Services Permission [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8]. If it also does insurance activities as a Captive Insurer or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay an extra $5,000 each year for those activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].
rag_answer: A company that operates as a Cell Company and engages in insurance activities must adhere to specific fee requirements. Firstly, such a company must pay an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell it wishes to add after obtaining its Financial Services Permission [#P:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8]. Additionally, there is an annual supervision fee of $8,000 for the Cell Company itself, plus an extra $1,000 for each individual Cell [#P:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. These fees are in addition to any other fees specified in Rules 3.11.1 to 3.11.4, which apply to Authorised Persons carrying on regulated activities such as Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as an Insurer, Captive Insurer, or Insurance Special Purpose Entity [#P:dec31cbb-1377-4ccf-9b40-b8810ee6a2af]. It is important to note that for Insurers operating through Cells, the Long Term Insurance risk component is zero concerning the Minimum Non Cellular Capital Requirement [#P:599f5527-826a-45fa-a0eb-940e433e32ee]. These structured fees ensure that the regulatory framework is maintained while allowing the flexibility of operating as a Cell Company.

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to amend a Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business, what are the fee requirements, and how do these requirements interact with the fees for undertaking additional Regulated Activities?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. If the amendment also involves undertaking additional Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with those activities at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. Each additional Regulated Activity incurs an additional fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the fee specified in the Rules [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2].
rag_answer: When an Authorised Person seeks to amend a Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business, they must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator. This fee is specifically for amending the scope of the existing Financial Services Permission to include Islamic Financial Business, either through the operation of an Islamic Window or as an Islamic Financial Institution [#P:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. Additionally, if the Authorised Person is also applying to undertake additional Regulated Activities, they must pay the respective application fees for each of those activities as well [#P:f9c4b46e-cf32-4d9f-ac00-1507ba0d5fc3]. It is important to note that the fee for conducting Islamic Financial Business is separate and in addition to any fees for other Regulated Activities the Authorised Person may wish to undertake [#P:d8b4725b-f1fc-41bf-947d-fc6e5b969ec2]. Therefore, the total fees payable will be the sum of the $5,000 for the Islamic Financial Business amendment and any additional fees for other Regulated Activities. This ensures that all activities fall within the scope of the Authorised Persons Financial Services Permissions as required by the Regulator [#P:f9c4b46e-cf32-4d9f-ac00-1507ba0d5fc3].

question: What are the fee obligations for an Authorised Person amending a Financial Services Permission to serve Retail Clients, and how do these obligations compare to those for adding multiple Regulated Activities?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person amending a Financial Services Permission to serve Retail Clients must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator, unless the amendment is pursuant to Rule 3.20.1 [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. In contrast, if the amendment involves adding multiple Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for those activities [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. Additionally, each additional Regulated Activity incurs an extra fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the fee specified in the Rules [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2].
rag_answer: To amend a Financial Services Permission to serve Retail Clients, an Authorised Person must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator. This fee is specific to amendments for serving Retail Clients and is distinct from fees associated with adding Regulated Activities. [#P:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] In contrast, when an Authorised Person seeks to amend a Financial Services Permission to undertake additional Regulated Activities, they must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the activities being applied for, plus an additional fee for each new activity, which is the lesser of $10,000 or the specified application fee for that activity. [#P:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] Thus, while the fee for serving Retail Clients is a flat rate, the fee for adding multiple Regulated Activities can vary depending on the specific activities and their associated fees. This distinction highlights the different financial obligations depending on the nature of the amendment to the Financial Services Permission.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to change their Financial Services Permission to include Islamic Financial Business, what fee do they pay, and how does this relate to fees for adding more Regulated Activities?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay a $5,000 fee to change their Financial Services Permission to include Islamic Financial Business [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. If they also want to add more Regulated Activities, they must pay the highest fee for those activities at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. Each new activity costs an extra fee, which is the lesser of $10,000 or the fee in the Rules [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2].
rag_answer: If an Authorised Person wishes to amend their Financial Services Permission to include Islamic Financial Business, they must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator. This fee is specifically for the amendment to conduct Islamic Financial Business, either through an Islamic Window or as an Islamic Financial Institution [#P:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. This fee is separate from any additional fees that may be required for adding other Regulated Activities. When an Authorised Person applies to amend their Financial Services Permission to undertake additional Regulated Activities, they must pay application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1, which are distinct from the fee for Islamic Financial Business [#P:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. Therefore, if the amendment involves both adding Islamic Financial Business and other Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person would need to pay the respective fees for each type of amendment. It is important to ensure that all activities fall within the scope of the Authorised Persons Financial Services Permissions as required by the Regulator [#P:f9c4b46e-cf32-4d9f-ac00-1507ba0d5fc3].

question: What fee does an Authorised Person pay to change their Financial Services Permission to serve Retail Clients, and how does this compare to fees for adding more activities?

Thus, the financial implications of amending a Financial Services Permission to serve Retail Clients are consistent with those for adding other Regulated Activities.

question: What are the application fee requirements for an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business, and how do these compare to the fees for an Applicant seeking permission to offer OTC Leveraged Products to Retail Clients?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. In comparison, an Applicant seeking a Financial Services Permission to offer OTC Leveraged Products to Retail Clients must pay a significantly higher application fee of $40,000 [#P:4b50eff1-6ea8-4b11-bead-95554b1f50de]. The fee for Islamic Financial Business is consistent with other amendments to a Financial Services Permission, such as enabling service to Retail Clients or removing a condition, which also require a $5,000 fee [#P:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. question: What is the fee for changing a permission to serve Retail Clients, and how does it compare to the fee for offering OTC Leveraged Products to Retail Clients?
gold_answer: The fee for changing a permission to serve Retail Clients is $5,000 [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. In contrast, the fee for offering OTC Leveraged Products to Retail Clients is $40,000 [#TGT:4b50eff1-6ea8-4b11-bead-95554b1f50de].

[#P:4b50eff1-6ea8-4b11-bead-95554b1f50de] [#P:9cd70946-8f57-45b7-83e2-c09e08c6b432] This fee structure applies to both the application process and the annual supervision fee for Authorised Persons who wish to engage in activities related to OTC Leveraged Products with Retail Clients. The significant fee reflects the additional regulatory scrutiny and obligations associated with offering complex financial products to Retail Clients, who may require more protection due to their potentially lower level of financial sophistication compared to professional clients. It is important for any Applicant or Authorised Person to ensure compliance with all relevant regulatory requirements, including conducting a thorough assessment of the Retail Client's skill, experience, and financial resources before offering such products. [#P:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] Additionally, the products offered must meet specific criteria, such as having a transparent pricing mechanism and not relating to non-financial instruments or binary options. [#P:37d3832a-a24c-4d89-85e7-c8e93214b397]

question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person pay both the additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 and the annual supervision fee of $100,000 to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to pay both the additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 and the annual supervision fee of $100,000 to the Regulator when it engages in specific combinations of Regulated Activities. The $100,000 fee applies when the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Accepting Deposits or Providing Credit [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. Additionally, the $10,000 fee is required if the Authorised Person carries on both Regulated Activities in Rule 3.3.2 or the activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Therefore, if the Authorised Person is involved in Providing Credit and either Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account, both fees are applicable.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both the additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 and the annual supervision fee of $100,000 to the Regulator under specific circumstances. Firstly, the Authorised Person must have a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of either Accepting Deposits or Providing Credit, which incurs an annual supervision fee of $100,000 [#P:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. Additionally, if the Authorised Person also carries on both Regulated Activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit, or both Regulated Activities specified in Rule 3.3.2, they must pay an additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 [#P:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Furthermore, if the Authorised Person undertakes multiple Regulated Activities, they must pay the highest of the relevant supervision fees, and each additional Regulated Activity incurs an additional fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the supervision fee associated with that activity [#P:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6]. Therefore, the combination of these conditions results in the obligation to pay both fees.

question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 fee to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 fee to the Regulator when it conducts certain financial activities. The $100,000 fee is due if the Authorised Person is allowed to Accept Deposits or Provide Credit [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. The $10,000 fee is required if the Authorised Person does both activities in Rule 3.3.2 or manages a Profit Sharing Investment Account and provides credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. So, if the Authorised Person provides credit and either accepts deposits or manages a profit-sharing account, both fees apply.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 fee to the Regulator when they engage in specific combinations of Regulated Activities. Specifically, this situation arises when an Authorised Person carries on both the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Providing Credit, which incurs a $100,000 fee, and any of the activities listed under the $10,000 fee category, such as Arranging Credit, Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility, or Managing a Collective Investment Fund, among others [#P:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d][#P:34dec4b2-2a31-4f2e-b595-1633fe9ef610]. Additionally, if the Authorised Person carries on both Accepting Deposits and Providing Credit, they must pay an extra $10,000, bringing the total to $110,000 for those activities alone [#P:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Therefore, the combination of these activities results in the obligation to pay both fees, reflecting the broader scope of financial services being provided.

question: What is the application fee requirement for an Applicant seeking a Financial Services Permission to conduct both Currency Exchange and Money Remittance activities under the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services?
gold_answer: An Applicant intending to conduct both Currency Exchange and Money Remittance activities under the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services must pay an application fee of $25,000 to the Regulator [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019]. This fee is specified for Applicants engaging in both activities as detailed in Rule 3.9.1 [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019]. The table in the TARGET passage confirms that the fee for either Currency Exchange or Money Remittance alone is $15,000, but the SOURCE specifies a combined fee for both activities [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b].
rag_answer: An Applicant seeking a Financial Services Permission to conduct both Currency Exchange and Money Remittance activities under the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services is required to pay an application fee of $25,000. This fee applies when an Applicant intends to conduct both activities as detailed in the relevant regulatory provisions. Specifically, the regulation states that if an Applicant will conduct both Currency Exchange and Money Remittance, the combined application fee is set at $25,000, which is the same as the fee for Payment Services alone. This fee structure is designed to streamline the application process for Applicants engaging in multiple related activities under the umbrella of Providing Money Services. There are no additional timing, record-keeping, or notification requirements specified for this particular fee structure beyond the standard application process. It is important for Applicants to ensure that they are aware of and comply with all relevant regulatory requirements when applying for Financial Services Permissions. [#P:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] [#P:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]

This fee is specific to the activities of Currency Exchange or Money Remittance as outlined in the regulatory framework [#P:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]. Once authorized, the individual or entity must also pay an annual supervision fee of $15,000 to continue operating under these regulated activities [#P:7f5d3d48-b019-4674-bde8-4e7352ac3709]. It is important to note that these fees are separate from any other financial obligations that may arise from offering additional services, such as Payment Services, which have their own distinct fee structure. question: How much does a company have to pay each year if it has permission to do both Currency Exchange and Payment Services?
gold_answer: A company with permission to do both Currency Exchange and Payment Services must pay an annual fee of $25,000 to the Regulator. question: When a Recognised Body applies for activities related to Spot Commodities, what fees are applicable, and how does this relate to an Applicant seeking permission to deal in investments as a principal?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body, which may be a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House, must adhere to the fees outlined in Section 4.1 when applying for activities concerning Spot Commodities [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]. In contrast, an Applicant seeking a Financial Services Permission to engage in the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, but not as a Matched Principal, is required to pay an application fee of $40,000 to the Regulator [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c].
rag_answer: When a Recognised Body applies for activities related to Spot Commodities, the fees specified in Section 4.1 are applicable, as these activities are undertaken by a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House [#P:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]. This is distinct from an Applicant seeking permission to deal in investments as a principal, where the application fee is $25,000 for the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal as a Matched Principal, or as an Agent [#P:2b7cadc6-ae87-409f-82a5-9488c046fd21]. The fees for Spot Commodities activities by a Recognised Body do not specify an amount in the provided context, indicating that they are covered under a different fee structure than individual applicants for dealing in investments. It is important for applicants to identify whether they are applying as a Recognised Body or as an individual entity, as this determines the applicable fee structure. Additionally, if an applicant is seeking to operate a Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity, a higher fee of $125,000 applies [#P:e656b001-88b4-480f-9f22-1e5557d57849].

question: If a Recognised Body wants to do activities with Spot Commodities, what fees do they need to pay, and how is this different from someone applying to deal in investments as a principal?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body, such as a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House, must pay the fees specified in Section 4.1 for activities related to Spot Commodities [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]. On the other hand, an Applicant who wants to deal in investments as a principal, but not as a Matched Principal, must pay a $40,000 application fee to the Regulator [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c].
rag_answer: If a Recognised Body, such as a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House, intends to engage in activities related to Spot Commodities, they are required to pay the fees specified in Section 4.1 of the relevant regulatory document. This is distinct from the fees applicable to an applicant seeking a Financial Services Permission to deal in investments as a principal. For such applicants, the fees are determined based on the specific Regulated Activity they propose to undertake. Specifically, an applicant must pay an application fee of $20,000, or $125,000 if the activity involves Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity [#P:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49][#P:e656b001-88b4-480f-9f22-1e5557d57849]. The distinction lies in the fact that Recognised Bodies follow a different fee structure as outlined in Section 4.1, which is not detailed in the provided context, whereas applicants for dealing in investments as a principal have specific fees based on the nature of their activities. This ensures that the fee structure is tailored to the type of entity and the nature of the activities they are undertaking.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator impose a supplementary fee in addition to the standard application fee for a proposed new Controller or a change in the Holding of an existing Controller?
gold_answer: The Regulator may impose a supplementary fee in addition to the standard application fee of $1,000 when certain conditions are met. These conditions include situations where the Controller is from a jurisdiction lacking an adequate memorandum of understanding with the Regulator, or if the Controller proposes changes to the business model, activities, or senior management of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. Additionally, a supplementary fee may be charged if the application requires the Regulator to incur substantial additional expense or effort due to its complexity [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. The standard application fee of $1,000 is applicable for any Authorised Person or Recognised Body seeking approval for a new Controller or a change in the Holding of an existing Controller [#TGT:db5cfcd0-4783-4652-b75b-d9eee44a9873].
rag_answer: The Regulator may impose a supplementary fee in addition to the standard application fee for a proposed new Controller or a change in the Holding of an existing Controller under specific circumstances. Firstly, if the Controller is from a jurisdiction lacking an adequate memorandum of understanding with the Regulator, a supplementary fee may be charged [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. Additionally, if the Controller intends to alter the business model, activities, or senior management of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body, this could also trigger a supplementary fee [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. Furthermore, if the application is complex and requires the Regulator to incur substantial additional expenses or effort, a supplementary fee may be warranted [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. The supplementary fee reflects the Regulators reasonable estimate of the additional resources needed, which may include complex applications due to the applicant's profile, intense supervisory scrutiny, or novel proposals that cover untested areas of the regulatory regime [#P:33127e68-bce1-4ef1-a2b8-86217e654659]. These fees ensure that the Regulator can adequately address the complexities and risks associated with such applications.

question: When can the Regulator ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee for a new Controller or change in Holding?
gold_answer: The Regulator can ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee if the Controller is from a place without a proper agreement with the Regulator, or if they want to change the business model, activities, or senior managers of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. More money can also be required if the application is very complex and needs extra work or costs [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. These conditions ensure that the Regulator can cover the additional resources required to assess more complex or potentially riskier applications. question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person pay both an application fee and a supplementary fee when applying to establish a branch outside ADGM?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with its registered head office in ADGM must pay an application fee when applying to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM. This fee is calculated as 50% of the highest application fee specified in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities intended at the new branch [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. Additionally, a supplementary fee may be charged by the Regulator if the proposed branch is to operate in a jurisdiction lacking an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both an application fee and a supplementary fee when applying to establish a branch outside ADGM if the branch is to operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator. The application fee is calculated as 50% of the highest application fee for the Regulated Activities the branch intends to undertake, as specified in Chapter 3 of the Rules [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. In addition to this, a supplementary fee may be charged by the Regulator if the jurisdiction lacks an adequate memorandum of understanding, which ensures regulatory cooperation and oversight [#P:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. This supplementary fee is intended to cover any additional regulatory efforts or complexities that may arise due to the absence of such an agreement. Therefore, the key precondition for the supplementary fee is the lack of an adequate memorandum of understanding with the jurisdiction where the branch is to be established. The Authorised Person must ensure compliance with these fee requirements to successfully establish the branch.

question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay extra fees to set up a branch outside ADGM?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay an application fee when seeking approval to set up a branch outside ADGM, which is 50% of the highest fee listed in Chapter 3 for the activities they plan to do [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. They also have to pay a supplementary fee if the branch will be in a place where there is no proper agreement between the Regulator and the local financial regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person with its registered head office in ADGM must pay additional fees when applying to establish a branch outside ADGM. Specifically, the Authorised Person is required to pay an application fee to the Regulator, which is calculated as 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of the relevant Rules for the Regulated Activities it intends to conduct from the proposed branch [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. Furthermore, once the branch is established and operational, the Authorised Person must also pay an annual supervision fee. This fee is similarly calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to the Regulated Activities conducted from the branch. The initial supervision fee is prorated and must be paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a) [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c]. These financial obligations are part of the regulatory requirements for maintaining compliance when expanding operations beyond the ADGM.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator impose a supplementary fee on an Authorised Person with a branch conducting Regulated Activities outside ADGM, and how is the annual supervision fee determined for such a branch?
gold_answer: The Regulator may impose a supplementary fee on an Authorised Person if the branch operates in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must pay an annual supervision fee to the Regulator, which is calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities conducted from the branch [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c].

question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay extra fees for a branch outside ADGM, and how is the regular fee for that branch calculated?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay extra fees if their branch is in a place where there is no proper agreement between the Regulator and the local financial regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. question: What are the obligations of a Fund Manager when filing a Prospectus for a Domestic Fund under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), and how do these obligations differ if the Fund is a Public Fund?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund is required to produce a Prospectus in compliance with the specified rules [#TGT:ad985b09-6deb-42ae-b6fd-b7c90e850f98]. If the Domestic Fund is classified as a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must also file a copy of the Prospectus with the Regulator [#TGT:ad985b09-6deb-42ae-b6fd-b7c90e850f98]. This filing must be done pursuant to FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b) [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae].
rag_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund has specific obligations when filing a Prospectus under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b). The primary obligation is to produce a Prospectus in accordance with the requirements set out in the relevant rules. If the Domestic Fund is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must also file a copy of the Prospectus with the Regulator [#P:ad985b09-6deb-42ae-b6fd-b7c90e850f98]. Additionally, for an Islamic Fund that is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must comply with the additional requirements specified in IFR 6, which are supplementary to the general Prospectus requirements outlined in Chapter 9 of the Fund Rules [#P:4f4355b7-df95-44d4-9354-45e05ac580f8]. These obligations ensure that the Prospectus is not only produced but also appropriately filed and compliant with any additional requirements specific to the type of fund being managed. This structured approach helps maintain transparency and regulatory compliance in the offering of fund units.

question: When a Fund Manager issues a Supplementary Prospectus under Rule 9.3.1(3), what are the requirements for filing and distribution, and how do these relate to the filing of a Prospectus under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b)?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager issues a Supplementary Prospectus under Rule 9.3.1(3), it must clearly identify the original Prospectus it supplements, including revisions, the date of any material change, and the document's filing date with the Regulator [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. If the Fund is a Public Fund, a copy must be filed with the Regulator [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. Additionally, the Supplementary Prospectus must be provided to each Person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. The Supplementary Prospectus must also be made available in the same media and channels as the original Prospectus [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. This process is related to the filing of a Prospectus pursuant to FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), which establishes the initial requirement for filing a Prospectus [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae].
rag_answer: When a Fund Manager issues a Supplementary Prospectus under Rule 9.3.1(3), they must adhere to specific filing and distribution requirements. Firstly, the Supplementary Prospectus must clearly identify the original Prospectus it supplements, detail the revisions, and include the date of any material change or new matter, as well as the date of filing with the Regulator [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. If the Fund is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must file a copy of the Supplementary Prospectus with the Regulator and pay a filing fee of $3,000 [#P:079a9550-0459-4548-9324-edd1ecc2dbf4]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must provide a copy to each person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change or new matter [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. The Supplementary Prospectus must also be made available in the same media and through the same channels as the original Prospectus [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. These requirements align with the filing of a Prospectus under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), which also necessitate filing with the Regulator [#P:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae].

question: If a Fund Manager needs to issue a Supplementary Prospectus, what must they do with it, and how does this connect to filing a Prospectus under certain FUNDS Rules?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager issuing a Supplementary Prospectus must identify the original Prospectus it updates, note any changes, and include the filing date with the Regulator [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. For a Public Fund, a copy must be filed with the Regulator [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. The Supplementary Prospectus should be given to anyone who applied for Units but hasn't received them yet, after any changes occurred [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. It must also be available in the same way as the original Prospectus [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. This connects to the filing of a Prospectus under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), which requires the initial filing of a Prospectus [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae].
rag_answer: To issue a Supplementary Prospectus, a Fund Manager must follow specific procedures to ensure compliance with the relevant FUNDS Rules. Firstly, the Fund Manager must clearly identify the original Prospectus being supplemented, detail the revisions, and include the date of any material change or new matter, as well as the date of filing with the Regulator [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. If the Fund is a Public Fund, a copy of the Supplementary Prospectus must be filed with the Regulator [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must provide a copy to each person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. The Supplementary Prospectus must be made available through the same media and channels as the original Prospectus [#P:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. Furthermore, the Fund Manager must inform applicants of their right to confirm or retract their application and obtain a refund, allowing them at least seven days to do so from receipt of the Supplementary Prospectus [#P:6d382095-e701-44a7-b086-e3c3cc6170ae]. These steps ensure transparency and protect the interests of potential investors.

question: When a Fund Manager issues a Replacement Prospectus under Rule 9.3.1(3), what are the specific filing and notification requirements, and how do these relate to the filing obligations under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b)?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager issues a Replacement Prospectus pursuant to Rule 9.3.1(3), the Fund Manager must adhere to several specific requirements. Firstly, the Replacement Prospectus must clearly state that it is a replacement, identify the original Prospectus it replaces, and provide details of any material changes or new matters that necessitated the replacement, including the expiry date and the date of the document, which must coincide with the filing date with the Regulator [#TGT:9a77926a-fbd0-449d-ae52-9a3c6b4696bc]. Additionally, if the Replacement Prospectus pertains to a Public Fund, the Fund Manager is required to file a copy with the Regulator [#TGT:9a77926a-fbd0-449d-ae52-9a3c6b4696bc]. This filing requirement aligns with the obligations under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), which govern the filing of a Prospectus [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae]. Furthermore, the Fund Manager must provide a copy of the Replacement Prospectus to each person who applied for, but has not yet received, Units under the previous Prospectus, following the earliest date of any material change or new matter [#TGT:9a77926a-fbd0-449d-ae52-9a3c6b4696bc].
rag_answer: When a Fund Manager issues a Replacement Prospectus under Rule 9.3.1(3), they must adhere to specific filing and notification requirements. The Replacement Prospectus must clearly state that it is a replacement, identify the Prospectus it replaces, and include the date and nature of any material change or new matter, the expiry date, and the date of the document, which must be the date of filing with the Regulator [#P:9a77926a]. If the Fund is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must file a copy of the Replacement Prospectus with the Regulator [#P:9a77926a]. Additionally, the Fund Manager is required to provide a copy to each person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change or new matter [#P:9a77926a]. These requirements are in line with the obligations under FUNDS Rules 9.2.1(b), 9.4.2(1)(b), or 9.4.2(2)(b), which pertain to the filing of a Prospectus, ensuring that the Regulator is kept informed of any significant updates or changes to the Prospectus [#P:e4deea41]. This process ensures transparency and compliance with regulatory standards.

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator refrain from transmitting a notice of intent to use passporting procedures, and what subsequent actions are required if the notice is transmitted?
gold_answer: The Regulator must refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it determines that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply, or may not comply in the future, with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if it is necessary to further its objectives [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. If the notice is transmitted, the Regulator must, within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2, notify the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be promoted [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. Following confirmation from the Host Regulator(s) that the Register of Passported Funds has been updated, the Regulator must publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register and notify the Fund Manager of the completion of registration [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7].
rag_answer: The Regulator must refrain from transmitting a notice of intent to use passporting procedures if the name of the Passported Fund is not available for use in the relevant Host Jurisdiction due to it being already in use or subject to restrictions. In such cases, the Regulator is required to instruct the Fund Manager to immediately cease the Promotion of the Passported Fund and to adopt an alternative name as soon as practicable to re-commence Promotion [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f]. If the notice is transmitted, the Regulator must, within five Business Days of receiving the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2 or Rule 3.2.2, notify the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) of the intent to use the passporting procedures [#P:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7][#P:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]. Following confirmation from the Host Regulator(s) that their Register of Passported Funds has been updated, the Regulator must publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete [#P:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7][#P:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e].

question: When should the Regulator not send a notice about using passporting procedures, and what happens if they do send it?
gold_answer: The Regulator should not send a notice if they think the Fund Manager or Private Fund doesn't follow the rules or might not in the future, or if holding back helps their goals [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. If they do send it, they must tell the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days about the plan to promote the Passported Fund [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. After the Host Regulator(s) update their Register, the Regulator must publish the Fund's details and inform the Fund Manager that registration is done [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7].
rag_answer: The Regulator should not send a notice about using passporting procedures if the name of the Passported Fund is not available for use in the relevant Host Jurisdiction due to it being already in use or subject to restrictions. In such cases, the Regulator must require the Fund Manager to immediately cease Promotion of the Passported Fund and adopt an alternative name to re-commence Promotion [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f]. If the Regulator does send the notice, they must do so within five Business Days of receiving the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2 or 3.2.2, and subject to the respective Rule 3.1.5 or 3.2.5, to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted [#P:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. Following confirmation from the Host Regulator that the Register of Passported Funds has been updated, the Regulator must publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete [#P:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e].

question: What actions must the Regulator take if a material change, error, or omission results in the Fund Manager's non-compliance with applicable legislation, and how does the timing of notification to the Host Regulator factor into this process?
gold_answer: If a material change, error, or omission leads to the Fund Manager's non-compliance with applicable legislation, the Regulator is required to take all necessary measures, which may include de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]. Concurrently, if the Fund Manager becomes aware of such a material change, error, or omission between the notification pursuant to Rule 3.1.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, they must promptly notify the Regulator in writing [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6]. The Regulator will then promptly inform the relevant Host Regulator of all pertinent details [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].
rag_answer: If a material change, error, or omission results in the Fund Manager's non-compliance with applicable legislation, the Regulator is required to take all necessary measures, which may include de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds. This action is contingent upon the Regulator's assessment that such measures are necessary and appropriate under the circumstances [#P:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]. The process begins when the Fund Manager becomes aware of the material change, error, or omission and provides written notice to the Regulator without delay [#P:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6]. Upon receiving this notification, the Regulator must promptly inform the relevant Host Regulator of the details of the material change, error, or omission [#P:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc]. The timing of this notification is crucial as it ensures that the Host Regulator is aware of any issues before the commencement of Promotion in the Host Jurisdiction, allowing for any necessary regulatory actions to be taken in a timely manner. This process underscores the importance of prompt communication and regulatory compliance in maintaining the integrity of cross-jurisdictional fund promotions.

question: If a Fund Manager finds a big mistake or change that affects their compliance, what must they do, and how does the Regulator handle this with the Host Regulator?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager identifies a significant mistake or change affecting compliance, they must inform the Regulator in writing without delay [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6]. The Regulator is then responsible for taking necessary actions, which could include removing the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds if compliance with legislation is no longer possible [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]. Additionally, the Regulator will quickly share all relevant details with the Host Regulator [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].

Specifically, if the error or change results in non-compliance with applicable legislation or rules, the Fund Manager must inform the Regulator of the failure and the measures taken or planned to remedy the breach [#P:e0989104-fb19-4679-af83-f56a03c214d1]. The Regulator, upon being informed, will assess the situation and may take necessary actions, which could include de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds if deemed appropriate [#P:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]. This process ensures that both the Fund Manager and the Regulator are actively involved in maintaining compliance and addressing any significant issues promptly.

question: What are the obligations of the Regulator upon receiving a notice from the Fund Manager regarding the intention to use passporting procedures for a Public Fund?
gold_answer: Upon receiving a notice from the Fund Manager indicating the intention for a Public Fund to become a Passported Fund, the Regulator must act within five Business Days to notify the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) about the intent to use passporting procedures [#SRC:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]. This action is contingent upon the receipt of the notice as outlined in Rule 3.2.2 and subject to Rule 3.2.5 [#SRC:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]. Following confirmation from the Host Regulator that the Register of Passported Funds has been updated, the Regulator must publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete [#SRC:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]. The initial step of notifying the Regulator of the intention to use passporting procedures is a requirement for the Fund Manager [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37].
rag_answer: Upon receiving a notice from the Fund Manager regarding the intention to use passporting procedures for a Public Fund, the Regulator has specific obligations to ensure compliance with the relevant rules. Firstly, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator of its intention for the Public Fund to be a Passported Fund, which is a prerequisite for the passporting process to commence [#P:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37]. Additionally, the Fund Manager or its duly appointed Agent or Licensed Person is required to pay a notification fee to the Regulator at the time of notification and annually thereafter, as prescribed by the Fees Rules [#P:e1b06932-ba96-43b8-8c8c-2955a838b425]. The Regulator must ensure that these procedural and financial requirements are met before proceeding with any further actions related to the passporting of the Public Fund. Furthermore, the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund that is a Public Fund must comply with the minimum requirements for Public Funds as outlined in Appendix 1, which the Regulator must verify as part of its oversight responsibilities [#P:ad3fabf0-e15e-4d10-86ef-7b0197b17694]. These steps ensure that the passporting process is conducted in accordance with the established regulatory framework.

question: What happens after a Fund Manager tells the Regulator they want to use passporting for a Public Fund?
gold_answer: After a Fund Manager informs the Regulator about wanting to use passporting for a Public Fund, the Regulator must notify the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) within five Business Days [#SRC:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]. This is based on the Fund Manager's notification of their intention [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37]. rag_answer: After a Fund Manager notifies the Regulator of their intention to use passporting for a Public Fund, several steps must be followed. [#P:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37] Once the Public Fund is passported, the Fund Manager, along with its Agent and any other Licensed Person, is permitted to promote units in the Fund to both Retail Clients and Professional Clients. [#P:8020b9a2-c8ae-43b1-b618-d518c291dc53] However, if the Regulator receives notice from a Host Regulator that the name of the Passported Fund is not available or is restricted in the Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must immediately cease promotion of the Fund. The Fund must then adopt an alternative name as soon as practicable to resume promotion activities. [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f] These steps ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and facilitate the Fund's operations across jurisdictions.

question: What actions must the Regulator take if a material change, error, or omission affects the compliance of a Public Fund, and how does this relate to the notification process between the Fund Manager and the Regulator?
gold_answer: If a material change, error, or omission affects the compliance of a Public Fund, the Regulator must take all necessary measures, which may include de-registering the Public Fund from the Register of Passported Funds [#SRC:9845037b-efae-4710-b7ca-81473eac1aee]. This action is linked to the notification process, as the Fund Manager is required to notify the Regulator in writing without delay upon becoming aware of any such material change, error, or omission that is relevant to the notification pursuant to Rule 3.2.2 [#TGT:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc].

The notification process involves the Fund Manager providing written notice to the Regulator without delay if they become aware of any material change, error, or omission that is likely relevant to the notification previously given under Rule 3.2.2. The Regulator is then responsible for promptly informing the relevant Host Regulator of these details [#P:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must comply with provisions regarding notifying the Regulator of any proposed material alterations to the Fund's Constitution or Prospectus, and ensure that any fundamental or significant changes are communicated to Unitholders as required [#P:6eaf799a-dfb3-4652-bb3e-738d52f9447a]. question: What should happen if a Fund Manager finds a big mistake or change that affects a fund's compliance, and how does this connect to the notice they must give?
gold_answer: If a Fund Manager finds a significant mistake or change that affects a fund's compliance, the Regulator must take necessary actions, which might include removing the fund from the Register of Passported Funds [#SRC:9845037b-efae-4710-b7ca-81473eac1aee]. The Fund Manager's proactive communication and corrective measures are essential to maintain regulatory compliance and uphold the integrity of the fund's operations.

question: What are the obligations of the Regulator when a Fund Manager of a Private Fund notifies its intention to use the passporting procedures to promote a Passported Fund in a Host Jurisdiction?
gold_answer: Upon receiving a notice from a Fund Manager of a Private Fund indicating the intention to use passporting procedures, the Regulator must act within specific timeframes and follow certain procedures. Within five Business Days of receiving the notice, and considering any conditions set out in Rule 3.1.5, the Regulator is required to notify the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) about the intent to use passporting procedures for the Passported Fund [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. Once the Host Regulator(s) confirm that their Register of Passported Funds has been updated with the details of the Passported Fund, the Regulator must then publish these details on its own Register of Passported Funds and inform the Fund Manager that the registration process is complete [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. The initial notification from the Fund Manager is a prerequisite for these actions [#TGT:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb].

If the Regulator receives notice from a Host Regulator that the name of the Passported Fund is not available for use in the Host Jurisdiction, or if the name is subject to restrictions, the Regulator must require the Fund Manager to immediately cease the Promotion of the Passported Fund [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must ensure that the Passported Fund adopts an alternative name as soon as practicable to re-commence Promotion [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f]. These steps ensure that the Fund Manager complies with the regulatory requirements of both the Home and Host Jurisdictions, maintaining the integrity and legality of the fund's promotion activities.

question: What does the Regulator have to do when a Fund Manager wants to make a Private Fund a Passported Fund?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager tells the Regulator it wants a Private Fund to be a Passported Fund, the Regulator has specific steps to follow. First, within five Business Days of getting the notice, the Regulator must tell the Host Regulator(s) in the Host Jurisdiction(s) about the passporting intent [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. After the Host Regulator(s) update their Register of Passported Funds, the Regulator must publish the fund details on its own register and notify the Fund Manager that the registration is done [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. The process starts with the Fund Manager's notification [#TGT:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb].
rag_answer: When a Fund Manager wishes to make a Private Fund a Passported Fund, the Regulator's primary responsibility is to receive notification from the Fund Manager regarding its intention. question: What are the obligations of a Fund Manager when a material change occurs after notifying the Regulator of its intention to use passporting procedures for a Private Fund?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager intends to use the passporting procedures for a Private Fund, it must first notify the Regulator of this intention [#TGT:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb]. If, after this notification and before the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is likely relevant to the notification, it is required to inform the Regulator in writing without delay [#SRC:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6]. The Regulator will then promptly communicate these details to the relevant Host Regulator [#SRC:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].
rag_answer: When a material change occurs after a Fund Manager has notified the Regulator of its intention to use passporting procedures for a Private Fund, the Fund Manager has specific obligations to ensure compliance with applicable legislation. Additionally, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator of any material events as soon as practicable, and no later than seven days after becoming aware of such events. These events include, but are not limited to, the intention to retire as manager, the proposal of a successor manager, the removal or replacement of the manager, changes to material service providers, amendments to the Prospectus, commencement of winding-up, or intentions to vary or revoke the Financial Service Permission [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. It is crucial for the Fund Manager to adhere to these notification requirements to maintain regulatory compliance and avoid potential de-registration.

question: What should a Fund Manager do if something important changes after telling the Regulator they want to use passporting for a Private Fund?

Additionally, if a material change, error, or omission results in the Fund Manager no longer complying with applicable legislation, the Regulator may take necessary measures, including potentially de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds [#P:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]. This process ensures that the Fund Manager remains in compliance with ADGM regulations and maintains the integrity of the passporting status.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) despite the requirement to provide notice of intent to use passporting procedures within five Business Days?
gold_answer: The Regulator may refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it determines that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation, or if it has reasonable grounds to believe that they may not comply in the future [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. question: What are the obligations of a Fund Manager when a material change occurs after notifying the Regulator of its intention to use passporting procedures for a Public Fund?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager intends to use passporting procedures for a Public Fund, it must notify the Regulator of this intention [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, which include changes such as the intention to retire as manager, appointment of a successor manager, or any amendments to the Prospectus, among others [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. This notification must occur no later than seven days after the Fund Manager becomes aware of the event [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. These obligations ensure that the Regulator is kept informed of significant changes that could impact the compliance status of the Passported Fund, allowing for appropriate regulatory oversight and action if necessary.

question: What are the conditions under which a Passported Fund may be promoted in ADGM, and what is the role of the Regulator in updating the Register of Passported Funds?
gold_answer: A Passported Fund may be promoted in ADGM once the Register of Passported Funds has been updated pursuant to Rule 4.1.2, in accordance with applicable legislation, including these Rules [#SRC:56149e4f-fe51-4be1-88d0-dcc6f2487240]. For a Private Fund, promotion is limited to Professional Clients in ADGM, while a Public Fund may be promoted to any Persons in ADGM [#SRC:56149e4f-fe51-4be1-88d0-dcc6f2487240]. The Regulator plays a crucial role by updating the Register of Passported Funds promptly after receiving a transmission from a Home Regulator indicating that a fund is a Passported Fund [#TGT:a3e7ca71-f2a9-4124-b7c4-daa8b5823df7]. The Regulator must also notify the relevant Home Regulator once the update is completed [#TGT:a3e7ca71-f2a9-4124-b7c4-daa8b5823df7].
rag_answer: A Passported Fund may be promoted in the Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM) under specific conditions. Firstly, the Passported Fund must be included in the Register of Passported Funds, which is updated pursuant to Rule 4.1.2. Once updated, a Private Fund can be promoted to Professional Clients, while a Public Fund can be promoted to any persons in ADGM [#P:56149e4f-fe51-4be1-88d0-dcc6f2487240]. The Fund Manager, its Agent, and any other Licensed Person domiciled in the Home Jurisdiction can promote the Passported Fund in ADGM without needing further authorization from the Regulator, provided that ADGM is listed as a Host Jurisdiction on the relevant Registers of Passported Funds maintained by both the Regulator and the Home Jurisdiction's Authority [#P:2c921170-4bde-432d-b329-a7b288af62ee]. Additionally, these entities must comply with the legislation applicable in their Home Jurisdiction while promoting the fund in ADGM [#P:0074070f-2ba7-4aca-95f9-6f4b15a3cb2b]. Promotion must cease immediately if the fund is removed from either the Home Jurisdictions or the Regulators Register of Passported Funds [#P:4c5ee9d4-60c3-4a61-a020-402dbb168f7c]. These conditions ensure that the promotion of Passported Funds in ADGM is conducted within a regulated framework.

question: What are the notification requirements for a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund when the Prospectus is amended or replaced, and how does this relate to the prescribed form directed by the Regulator?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and no later than seven days after becoming aware, if the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. This notification must include reasonable detail of the event and a copy of the new Prospectus, in a form prescribed by the Regulator [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

When issuing a Replacement Prospectus, the Fund Manager must clearly state that it is a Replacement Prospectus, identify the Prospectus it replaces, and provide details of any material changes or new matters that prompted the replacement. Additionally, the Fund Manager must file a copy with the Regulator if it is a Public Fund and provide a copy to each person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change or new matter [#P:9a77926a-fbd0-449d-ae52-9a3c6b4696bc]. These steps ensure that all stakeholders are informed of significant changes and maintain compliance with regulatory requirements.

Additionally, if it is a Public Fund, a copy must be filed with the Regulator, and a copy must be provided to each person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of any material change or new matter [#P:9a77926a-fbd0-449d-ae52-9a3c6b4696bc].

gold_answer: The Fund Manager must tell the Regulator as soon as possible, and no later than seven days after they know about the change, if the Prospectus for a Passported Fund is changed [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. They need to include details of what happened and a copy of the new Prospectus in the notification, which must be in the form the Regulator says to use [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

This notification is a requirement under the applicable ADGM legislation for material events concerning Passported Funds. The notification must be made by the Fund Manager, the governing body, or the trustee of the Passported Fund. The obligation to notify the Regulator is part of a broader set of requirements that apply to various significant events related to the management and operation of a Passported Fund. These include changes in management, service providers, and the commencement of winding-up procedures, among others. The notification process ensures that the Regulator is kept informed of significant changes that may affect the operation or governance of the Passported Fund. It is important for the Fund Manager to adhere to this notification requirement to maintain compliance with regulatory obligations. [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]

question: What steps must a Fund Manager take to notify the Regulator about changes to a Passported Fund's Prospectus, and what details must be included?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as they can, and within seven days of knowing about the change, if the Prospectus for a Passported Fund is updated [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notification must include details about the change and a copy of the new Prospectus, and it must be in the form that the Regulator requires [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

This notification is part of the broader obligation to inform the Regulator of any material events affecting the Passported Fund. question: What are the notification obligations of a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund regarding material events, and how does this relate to the Regulator's duty to inform the Host Regulator?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund is required to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, such as changes in management or amendments to the Prospectus, and must do so no later than seven days after becoming aware of such events [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Upon receiving such a notification, the Regulator is then obligated to notify the relevant Host Regulator of these changes without undue delay [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]. This process ensures that both the Regulator and the Host Regulator are kept informed of significant developments affecting the Passported Fund.
rag_answer: A Fund Manager of a Passported Fund has specific notification obligations regarding material events, which are crucial for maintaining regulatory compliance. The Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and no later than seven days after becoming aware of certain material events. These events include the intention to retire as manager, the proposal or appointment of a successor manager, the removal or replacement of the manager, changes in material service providers, amendments to the Prospectus, commencement of winding-up, or intentions to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Additionally, if the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission between the initial notification and the commencement of promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, they must promptly inform the Regulator. The Regulator, in turn, is responsible for promptly providing the relevant Host Regulator with all pertinent details of such changes, errors, or omissions [#P:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc]. This process ensures that both the Regulator and the Host Regulator are kept informed of significant developments affecting the Passported Fund, thereby facilitating effective oversight and regulatory coordination.

question: When a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund tells the Regulator about important changes, what must the Regulator do next?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund informs the Regulator about important changes, such as a new manager or changes to the Prospectus, the Regulator must then inform the Host Regulator about these changes without delay [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]. The Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as possible, and no later than seven days after knowing about the changes [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. This ensures that all relevant parties are aware of the changes promptly.
rag_answer: When a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund notifies the Regulator about important changes, the Regulator's primary obligation is to ensure compliance with the applicable ADGM legislation and to take any necessary actions to address the changes. The Regulator must be informed as soon as practicable, and no later than seven days after the Fund Manager becomes aware of certain material events, such as changes in management, amendments to the Prospectus, or the commencement of winding-up procedures [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. If the Regulator receives notice from a Host Regulator that the name of the Passported Fund is not available or is restricted in the Host Jurisdiction, the Regulator must require the Fund Manager to immediately cease Promotion of the Passported Fund and adopt an alternative name to resume Promotion [#P:a4d63709-521f-4b71-8d91-d08491b84b8f]. These actions ensure that the Fund Manager remains compliant with both local and host jurisdiction requirements, maintaining the integrity and legality of the Fund's operations across jurisdictions.

question: When a Fund Manager intends to notify the Regulator of a Fund's status as a Passported Fund, how are the fees calculated if the Fund is structured as an Umbrella Fund with multiple Sub-Funds or cells?
gold_answer: When a Fund Manager or its appointed Agent or Licensed Person notifies the Regulator of a Fund's intention to be a Passported Fund, a notification fee is required at the time of notification, followed by an annual fee as per the Fees Rules [#TGT:e1b06932-ba96-43b8-8c8c-2955a838b425]. If the Passported Fund is structured as an Umbrella Fund, including forms such as a segregated portfolio company or cell company, the prescribed fees must be paid for each individual Sub-Fund, segregated portfolio, or cell, rather than for the Umbrella Fund as a whole [#SRC:e953f6b5-a372-4f05-a7d2-251e5eee3684].
rag_answer: When a Fund Manager intends to notify the Regulator of a Fund's status as a Passported Fund, and the Fund is structured as an Umbrella Fund with multiple Sub-Funds or cells, the fees are calculated based on each individual Sub-Fund or cell rather than the Umbrella Fund as a whole. Specifically, the Fund Manager or its duly appointed Agent or Licensed Person must pay a notification fee to the Regulator at the time of notification and annually thereafter, as prescribed by the Fees Rules, for each Sub-Fund, segregated portfolio, or cell within the Umbrella Fund [#P:e1b06932-ba96-43b8-8c8c-2955a838b425]. This means that the prescribed fees must be paid separately for each Sub-Fund, segregated portfolio, or cell, rather than a single fee for the entire Umbrella Fund [#P:e953f6b5-a372-4f05-a7d2-251e5eee3684]. This approach ensures that each component of the Umbrella Fund is individually accounted for in terms of regulatory fees, reflecting the structure and complexity of the Fund.

question: If a Fund Manager wants to make a Fund a Passported Fund, how are fees handled for an Umbrella Fund with different parts?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager or its Agent must pay a notification fee to the Regulator when they notify that a Fund will be a Passported Fund, and then pay an annual fee as set by the Fees Rules [#TGT:e1b06932-ba96-43b8-8c8c-2955a838b425]. If the Fund is an Umbrella Fund, fees must be paid for each Sub-Fund or cell separately, not just for the Umbrella Fund itself [#SRC:e953f6b5-a372-4f05-a7d2-251e5eee3684].
rag_answer: To handle fees for an Umbrella Fund that a Fund Manager wants to make a Passported Fund, specific rules apply. When calculating fees, if the Passported Fund is an Umbrella Fund, including forms like a segregated portfolio company or cell company, the prescribed fees must be paid for each Sub-Fund, segregated portfolio, or cell, rather than for the Umbrella Fund as a whole [#P:e953f6b5-a372-4f05-a7d2-251e5eee3684]. Additionally, a Fund Manager of a Domestic Passported Fund is required to pay an annual passporting fee of $2,000 for each Domestic Passported Fund [#P:59196d44-7a16-4205-a05f-60b8c9c4cf62]. This means that for an Umbrella Fund with multiple Sub-Funds, the Fund Manager must pay the annual passporting fee for each Sub-Fund individually. It is important to ensure that these fees are calculated and paid correctly to comply with the regulatory requirements. There are no specific timing or notification requirements mentioned in the context, but adherence to these fee structures is crucial for regulatory compliance.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator refuse a Host Regulator's request for cooperation in an on-site inspection of a Passported Fund, and what obligations does the Regulator have if it permits the inspection?
gold_answer: The Regulator may refuse a Host Regulator's request for cooperation in an on-site inspection if enforcement action has already commenced or concluded, or if judicial proceedings have been initiated or concluded, concerning the same conduct and the same Persons [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. If these conditions do not apply and the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator, it must permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection, subject to Rule 9.3.2 [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6].
rag_answer: The Regulator may refuse a Host Regulator's request for cooperation in an on-site inspection of a Passported Fund if certain conditions are met. Specifically, the Regulator can decline the request if it has already commenced or concluded enforcement action regarding the same conduct and the same Persons, or if judicial proceedings have been initiated or concluded concerning the same conduct and the same Persons [#P:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. If the Regulator permits the inspection, it is obligated to allow the Host Regulator to carry out the on-site inspection and must accompany the Host Regulator during the inspection [#P:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]. These conditions ensure that the Regulator's actions are coordinated and do not duplicate efforts or interfere with ongoing legal processes.

question: When can the Regulator say no to a Host Regulator's request for help with inspecting a Passported Fund, and what must it do if it agrees to the inspection?
gold_answer: The Regulator can refuse a Host Regulator's request for help with an inspection if it has already started or finished enforcement action, or if court cases have begun or ended, for the same conduct and Persons [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. If these situations do not exist, the Regulator must allow the inspection and go along with it, unless Rule 9.3.2 applies [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6].
